list_definition.definition: (also Deutsche Mark, Deutschmarkˈdoitʃmaːk) the standard unit of German currency before the euro.
a point given as a reward for good work etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She got good marks in the exam.
That spilt coffee has left a mark on the carpet.

list_definition.definition: a sign used as a guide to position etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: There’s a mark on the map showing where the church is.

list_definition.mean_english: dấu chữ thập (của những người không biết viết
list_definition.definition: a cross or other sign used instead of a signature

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He couldn’t sign his name, so he made his mark instead.

list_definition.definition: an indication or sign of a particular thing
to put a mark or stain on, or to become marked or stained

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Every pupil’s coat must be marked with his or her name
That coffee has marked the tablecloth

list_definition.definition: to give marks to (a piece of work)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I have forty exam-papers to mark tonight.

list_definition.definition: to show; to be a sign of

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: X marks the spot where the treasure is buried.
Mark it down in your notebook.

list_definition.definition: (in football/soccer etc) to keep close to (an opponent) so as to prevent his getting the ball

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Your job is to mark the centre-forward.

There is also the question of marking pupils' or students' work.

A question mark (?) indicates that the pedigree is not fully resolved.
It is to be hoped that his lamented death did not occur too soon for him to leave his mark on the second volume.

The years between 1945 and 1970 were marked by significant social changes, which were particularly visible in the context of the lives of women.
